column1: #Text=Baghdad judge clears pair of murdering six foreign soldiers
#Text=A judge in Baghdad , Iraq has cleared two men of murdering six soldiers from the United Kingdom .
#Text=Hamza Hateer and Mussa Ismael al Fartusi had their case kicked out prior to trial owing to a lack of evidence ; they were alleged to be involved in a June 2003 mob attack on a police station .
#Text=At today 's hearing , which had been postponed by a month to allow witnesses to travel , a panel of three judges spent three and a half hours to question those who were there .
#Text=Sources disagree on the number of witnesses — between nine and eleven — none of whom said they had seen the accused participate in any violence .
#Text=Most of those questioned were Iraqi police .
#Text=They wanted justice for the killing of their relatives — Policeman and witness Ahmed Hassan Sayed

#Text=The killings in Majar al-Kabir followed a dispute at the local market in which British soldiers had argued with Iraqis over the use of dogs to search , which the locals were upset about , according to policeman Ahmed Hassan Sayed .
#Text=He said gunfire followed and the soldiers killed around ten people .
#Text=" I was inside the [ police ] station with the British soldiers .

column1: #Text=Although no witnesses saw either defendant engaged in violence , one stated that Hateer took a dead man 's weapon ; he will be tried for its theft .
#Text=The pair were among eight whose arrests were anounced in February ; six were released without charge .
#Text=Judge Balee Hamdi told The Guardian that in releasing the men " I built my decisions on the evidence that was before me .

#Text=He also said that should rebels be convicted before him  [ i]f they are here for resistance against occupiers , I will try to lessen the sentence . "

column1: #Text=A Ministry of Defence — the British organisation responsible for the country 's army — spokesman responded to the news by saying that she knew that the victim 's families will be " very disappointed , " but , they said , " we have no choice but to respect the decision of the Iraqi judges .
